description: Following the endorsement of the Global action plan on antimicrobial resistance through WHA68.7, Afghanistan as a WHO member state with technical support of the WHO country office, initiated the program and so far the following progress has made : 1.	National AMR focal point appointed, 2.	National Action Plan for AMR 2017-2021 developed, 3.	National Coordination Center (NCC) with the following governance structure established. ?	AMR-Technical Advisory Group on AMR (AMR-TAG) specific for human health sector with clear ToR and membership of the different related departments. ?	AMR-Core working group (AMR-CWG) specific for human health sector with clear ToR and membership of the different related departments.  4.	The country has enrolled in Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS) since 2018 with having : ?	 National AMR surveillance plan and  ?	GLASS sub-committee. 5.	One National Reference Laboratory performing Antimicrobial Sensitivity testing and one Hospital as Surveillance site are identified . Despite the fact the AMR has emerged as global public health problem leading to significant morbidity as well economic burden which need critical attention, however, the country has made some progress which need further investment for its institutionalization.
Angola is at the phase of implementing AMR Surveillance in the country, identifying local sentinels and coordinating  for lab data monthly report about the situation of AMR in the country.

The United Arab Emirates have been conducting surveillance of AMR since 2011 when the Abu Dhabi - Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Program (AD ARS) was introduced. In 2015, the program was expanded nationwide, under the Ministry of Health and Prevention. The National Action Plan on AMR is under development. UAE has enrolled in GLASS in April 2017.

The ?National Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Network: WHONET-Argentina? is coordinated by the Antimicrobial Agents Division (NRL in AMR) of the National Institute of Infectious Diseases-ANLIS "Dr. Carlos G. Malbrán??, Ministry of Health. Argentina is implementing the National Action Plan on AMR published in 2015. The country participates in ReLAVRA since 2000 and has been enrolled in GLASS in April 2019.

Australia released its second national AMR strategy, Australia?s National Antimicrobial Resistance Strategy: 2020 & Beyond, in March 2020. The Strategy aligns with the goal of the WHO Global Action Plan. Objective five of the Strategy aims for ?integrated surveillance and response to resistance and usage?. As such, Australia will continue to develop its One Health approach to surveillance by building on the existing Antimicrobial Use and Resistance in Australia (AURA) Surveillance System following further assessment across the animal, food and environment sectors. The AURA Surveillance System collects and reports data from partner programs across acute and community healthcare settings, and provides integrated reporting on priority organisms and antimicrobial use, and appropriateness of use, at a national level. The AURA Surveillance System published national reports in 2016, 2017 and 2019. Australia enrolled in the Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS) in April 2019 and contributed data on one of eight possible GLASS priority pathogen/specimen combinations in 2019 and on 6/8 in 2020.

Laboratories get samples. Laboratories report to national reference centre. National reference centre reports to MoH. MoH reports to ECDC. Austria checks if the data sent annually to ECDC via TESSy are correct. However although all reasonable precautions have been taken to verify the content provided by Austria into the TESSy platform, Austria makes no warranties, express or implied, regarding the content, presentation, appearance, completeness or accuracy of the Austrian data in TESSy. WHO may get Austrian EARS-Net Data from ECDC under the condition European Community Laws apply and especially the European Union Data Protection Laws are met. Austria does not check if data provided from ECDC to third parties are correct or complete. Austria makes no warranties, express or implied, regarding the content, presentation, appearance, completeness or accuracy of the data in the web-based internet GLASS platform. Austrian antimicrobial resistance data are published annually (AURES - starting with the year 2005) by the Austrian Health Authority (https://www.sozialministerium.at/Themen/Gesundheit/Antimikrobielle-Resistenzen-und-Gesundheitssystem-assoziierte-Infektionen/Antimikrobielle-Resistenzen/AURES---der-österreichische-Antibiotikaresistenz-Bericht.html)

We have 2 national laboratories and 7 sites which participate to the National AMR surveillance system (9 sites globally). During this end of 2020, we analyse the capacity of these sites in order to provide data, which will be reported to the GLASS.  We are working hard and we will start to report to the GLASS sooner.
Current AMR surveillance system is based on Case-based surveillance of clinical syndromes. But we are going to move towards Laboratory based surveillance within short time.

Bahrain has a National Action Plan on AMR approved in 2018. The functioning National AMR surveillance system produces regular reports and covers about 80% of the population. Bahrain has been enrolled in GLASS since October 2016

Bosnia and Herzegovina is engaged in the CAESAR network since 2015.  AMR surveillance activities are conducted by two networks; one in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and one in Republika Srpska.   The two surveillance networks comprise 12 laboratories: - six (50% of) laboratories in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, all of which submitted data; and - six (86% of) laboratories in the Republika Srpska, all of which submitted data.  Laboratories are geographically spread within Bosnia and Herzegovina. The estimated coverage of the population is 75% in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and 85% in Republika Srpska.  The network in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina comprises tertiary (17%), secondary (50%) and mixed tertiary and secondary (33%) care hospitals. The network in Republika Srpska comprises tertiary (50%) and secondary (50%) care hospitals.   Confirmatory testing of exceptional phenotypes or highly resistant microorganisms is performed at the expert laboratory (Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina) or locally (Republika Srpska).  In both networks the AMR focal point and the data manager are responsible for collecting data from the participating laboratories. Laboratories are asked to collect antimicrobial susceptibility results for the first isolate from blood and CSF for each patient, including patient information for the period 1 January  to 31 December for each year monitored. Laboratories check their data for adherence to the CAESAR protocol, microbiological consistency and plausibility and consistency with EUCAST guidelines before submitting the data. Confirmatory testing of highly resistant microorganisms is done before the results are included in the final dataset. The data manager and AMR focal point approve the data before electronic submission to CAESAR.

Currently, 6 labs provide AMR information for GLASS, located in one state, with 5 hospital with assistance to inpatient and outpatient and 1 Lab only for N. Gonorrheae that receive samples from all the country. The system is expanding to the rest of the country. Brazil have plans to implement EQA for these Labs. We are sure that 2 Labs participate in EQA programme.

ncc_established_address: Commonwealth Drive Bandar Seri Begawan Brunei Darussalam,  BB3910
nrl_designated_address: RIPAS Hospital, Bandar Seri Begawan, Brunei Darussalam, BA1710
description: In Brunei Darussalam, AMR is on the rise with the highest rate reported with carbapenem-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii followed by carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE). These pathogens can cause plethora of infections such as respiratory infection, bloodstream infection, urinary tract infection, meningitis and intra-abdominal infection.  Carbapenem is an important antibiotic of last resort to treat Gram-negative clinical infections. Unfortunately, carbapenem-resistant emerges due to the overuse and misuse of carbapenem antibiotics. Aggravating this problem further, is the carbapenemase gene acquired by these pathogens which are carried on plasmids. It is evident that these plasmid-borne carbapenemases (IMP-like, VIM-like, NDM-like and KPC-like) have disseminated globally, causing a public health threat and further limiting therapeutic options. Therefore, old drugs such as colistin had to be repurposed alongside unorthodox combination therapy.  It is therefore of paramount importance to ensure that AMR in Brunei Darussalam in the human sector is controlled in order to prevent the ?antibiotic apocalypse? where no more antibiotic can be used to stop infections. Implementing surveillance through the use of important diagnostic tools (phenotypic, rapid testing or genotypic) are key to prevent AMR.  In the context of our diagnostic routine National Clinical Microbiology Reference Laboratory, the AMR activities includes bacterial identification, antibiotic susceptibility testing and identification of antibiotic resistance genes (ARG) using rapid lateral flow assay tests. National Clinical Microbiology Reference Laboratory also participates in External Quality Assurance program from the RCPAQAP (Royal College of Pathologists Australasia Quality Assurance Programs) and WHO GASP (Gonococcal Antimicrobial Surveillance Programme).  In addition, the term of reference for the National Surveillance Centre (National Coordinating Centre) includes:  1.	To coordinate the AMR surveillance system. This includes the collation and aggregation of data from data reporting sites (human health). While the initial emphasis is on human clinical pathogens, in line with WHO, the expectation is that AMR surveillance, in the long term, be embedded in a One Health approach. In this context, it is expected that AMR surveillance systems will develop progressively to include agriculture (including animal health) and the environment.  2.	The agreed data reporting sites are as follows:  ?	Clinical Microbiology Laboratory, Department of Laboratory Services, Ministry of Health: -	AMR data according to WHO GLASS priority pathogens (selected) and antimicrobials -	To also include data from private laboratories  ?	Department of Pharmacy Services, Ministry of Health -	Antimicrobial consumption data in defined daily dose from public and private sectors for all antimicrobials  ?	Department of Agriculture & Agrifoods, Ministry of Primary Resources and Tourism -	Data on priority pathogens: E. coli, Salmonella, Campylobacter and S. aureus from food producing animals. -	Antimicrobial consumption data in animal population  3.	To conduct surveillance data analysis, either descriptive or analytical epidemiology, at national and/or sub-national level to inform any necessary interventions.  4.	Dissemination of data to Technical Working Group (TWG)-2 (surveillance and research) and other relevant stakeholders that can support and inform recommendations of Brunei Darussalam AMR Committee (BDAMRC) including a local antimicrobial prescribing guidelines and infection control policies.  5.	Collaborate with relevant stakeholders and international partners, including WHO, to ensure appropriate analysis of national and regional initiatives. This may include identification of capacity building activities, at national and international level, for data providers, analysts, and users.  6.	To assist TWG2 in providing an annual report of surveillance activities and key findings to BDAMRC.

AMR system in Bhutan is governed by National Action Plan for AMR (NAP-2018-2023). We have already designated NCC, NRL and Surveillance sites for the smooth implementation of AMR related activities. NCC coordinates all the AMR related activities and NRL provides technical support. We have one NRL and 4 surveillance sites with their defined terms of references and mandates. NRL and surveillance sites participates in external quality scheme that is in Newzealand (PPTC).

The Canadian Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (CARSS) is Canada's national focal point for surveillance of AMR and antimicrobial use. It integrates surveillance data from nine surveillance systems and laboratory reference services operated by the Public Health Agency of Canada and it's partners. The Federal Action Plan on Antimicrobial Resistance and Use in Canada was published in 2015. Canada has enrolled in GLASS in November 2016

The Swiss Antibiotic Resistance Centre (www.anresis.ch) was established in 2004, is located at the University of Berne and is financially supported by the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health and the University of Berne. It collects all routinely performed AMR results from actually 33 laboratories distributed all over Switzerland and covering >85% of all hospitalization days. Besides samples from hospitals, it also includes samples from private physicians and long term facilities. All participating laboratories are participating in at least one external quality program. AMR results are reported as delivered by the laboratories. All laboratories use EUCAST guidelines. For difficult to detect or new resistance mechanisms samples may be sent to the National Reference Center for Early Detection of New Antibiotic Resistance Mechanisms (https://www3.unifr.ch/med/nara/de/) for verification. ANRESIS is participating in CAESAR since 2010 and in GLASS since 2016.

- Mapping of multi-resistant bacteria in the health regions of Côte d'Ivoire (CDC-GHSA)  - Prevention and Control of Healthcare-Related Infections (MTaPS-USAID)  - Monitoring the emergence of resistance due to antibiotic residues in lagoon waters  - AMR Governance Implementation Meetings  - Drafting and validation of the national multisectoral action plan / Côte d'Ivoire - Establishment of the Multi-sectional Technical Committees and the GMC (multisectoral coordination group) in accordance with the strategic objectives of the national action plan.  - Development of a national guide for phenotypic and genotypic AMR detection that takes into account all microorganisms from the three sectors of humans, animals and the environment.

Data on resistance in the Czech Republic are provided by the National Reference Laboratory (NRL) for antibiotics at the National Institute of Public Health (SZÚ). The NRL for Antibiotics is the national coordinator of the European Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance Network (EARS-Net) and GLASS. NRL for Antibiotics monitors antibiotic resistance in the cause of invasive infections and also provides national surveillance of the most important community bacterial infectious agents (acquired outside healthcare facilities). NRL cooperates with working group for monitoring (antibiotic) resistance (PSMR) which was established in 1990. Since 2011, PSMR has joined representatives of more than 50 microbiological laboratories in the Czech Republic, whose catchment area covers approximately 80% of the population of the Czech Republic. Participation in PSMR is voluntary, PSMR members apply for individual projects according to the possibilities of the laboratory. All collected data are obtained in the process of normal daily routine under the conditions of good laboratory practice.
Data submitted to the GLASS was extracted from the national HAI & AMR surveillance implemented in the intensive care units in 39 hospitals in Egypt.

The National reference laboratory (Clinical  bacteriology and mycology) has a mandate to coordinate laboratory based AMR surveillance system. there is periodic microbiology mentor ship program and isolate and AST confirmation for all participating sentinel sites. Hospitals that participate in the AMR surveillance system submit data to NRL entering in whonet by email. The national data manager merge all the data, clean and submit to GLASS. Sentinel sites are at Addis Ababa, and different regions of the country.

Communicable Diseases Act (1227/2016) requires comprehensive surveillance of AMR. Both the public and animal health sectors have well-established AMR surveillance and reporting systems. Clinical laboratories in the public health sector perform susceptibility testing for all clinically important bacteria. All clinical microbiology laboratories including private laboratories are participating in surveillance. National Institute for Health and Welfare collects susceptibility data from clinical laboratories. Results are published yearly in the Finres report.

French current national AMR surveillance gathered two networks :  -  SPARES network collect data from voluntary hospital settings. Data collected included administrative data (number of patient-days) and laboratory data: susceptibility to various antibiotics of strains of Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus faecalis, Enterococcus faecium, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter baumannii and enterobacteriaceae isolated from diagnostic samples from inpatients. Data from 991 healthcare facilities accounting for 50% of hospital beds in France, were analysed in 2019. SPARES network also collect data on antibiotic consumption in healthcare settings.  - PRIMO network collect data from voluntary community laboratories on community patients or patients in LTCF. In 2019, 1 016 community laboratories and 230 hospital laboratories for LTCF have been involved in this surveillance. Data collected come in majority from strains isolated in unary samples.  In addition, data from three hospital laboratories networks (get together in Onerba network) are sent to ECDC as the French contribution to EARS-Net. In 2019, 193 laboratories for S. pneumoniae and 46 laboratories for the other EARS-Net pathogens participating in this surveillance.
Due to the challanges linked to data collection in hospitals, the AMR surveillance system is currently only based on the surveillance  done at the national reference laboratories

AMR surveillance in the UK is coordinated by Public Health England, Public Health Agency Northern Ireland, NHS National Servies Scotland and Public Health Wales. The UK has a Five Year National Action Plan (2019 to 2024) and a Twenty Year Vision for AMR. The UK participates in EARS-Net, Euro-GASP and FWD-Net and has been enrolled in GLASS since July 2017

NCDC is successful cooperation with the World Health Organization (WHO)  Recent Key Achievements -	Lugar Center, (International ISO 15189 accredited laboratory in microbiology/AMR) assists the  country with: standardization of laboratory diagnostic for AMR; development of technical guidelines, SOPs, procedures for laboratory methods/procedures; implementation of IQC/EQA program with appropriate technology;  provision of reference services. -	23 microbiological laboratories including Lugar Center (NCDC) are involved in WHO EQA Program.  -	National AMR reference laboratory capacity at Lugar Center has been strengthened in terms of antimicrobial resistance surveillance capability and verified and implemented phenotypic and molecular confirmatory tools of AMR mechanism, including sequencing  Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) isolates are screen for the presence of KPC, VIM, IMP, NDM, MOX/CMY and OXA48 using PCR (research capacity) AMR isolates are screen for the presence of KPC, NDM, OXA48, mcr1, mcr2 using qPCR (diagnostic capacity) Whole Genome Sequence analysis are conducted on Illumina Miseq platform for CRE isolates. -	The national AMR committee was created, where epidemiologists, veterinarians, infection disease, public health and environmental experts are working together; -	Infection prevention and control (IPC) legislation were updated -	Developed a new guidelines ?Infection prevention and control? and ?Infection prevention and control in dental clinics?  -	Developed and implemented a national plan for IPC monitoring and evaluation in health care settings -	Developed and conducted training programs of IPC modules for medical personnel -	Point Prevalence Survey (PPS) of Antimicrobial Consumption and Resistance was conducted according to the Global-PPS protocol in intensive care units of 10 multi-profile hospitals. -	The Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy (2018) has been translated and published -	Information on antibiotics (for humans) exported in Georgia is collected ? Antimicrobial Medicines Consumption network

Croatia established the Croatian Committee for Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance (CCARS) in 1996 and today the network gathers 35 microbiological laboratories and thus covers > 90% of Croatian population. The CCARS closely collaborates with the Reference Center for Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance that provides laboratory support for retesting alert organisms and conducting EQA. Croatia participates in EARSS/EARS-Net since 1999 and in GLASS since 2018. At the moment we collect data on isolates from blood, stool and genital specimens.

The Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS) was launched in 2015 with the goal of strengthening evidence on AMR to facilitate informed decision making and drive impactful interventions nationally, regionally and globally. 2019 marked the milestone where Indonesia successfully enrolled in GLASS. WHO facilitated the establishment of national AMR surveillance platform including National Coordination Center, National reference Laboratory and Sentinel Sites and mechanism; and supported capacity building of the national team on AMR surveillance system (GLASS) in Surabaya. Indonesia successfully participated and contributed AMR data to GLASS secretariat. MoH decided to include in total 11 hospitals as AMR surveillance sentinel sites and will be added to become 20 hospitals on this year; 2 national reference laboratories (BBLK Jakarta and BBLK Surabaya) and a National Coordinating Center (NIHRD). Due to COvid-19 situation, only 16 surveillance sites could be submitted AMR data to NCC completely Monitoring implementation of AMR surveillance will be conducted in 2021. Indonesia also completed the first phase of the Global Integrated Survey on ESBL producing E.coli-Tricycle Project which aimed to strengthen the antimicrobial resistance (AMR) surveillance system and promote integrated surveillance across human, animal and environment sectors using the One Health approach.  The project showed a substantial burden of ESBL E.coli in human, animal and environment from samples collected and is the first integrated AMR surveillance with One Health approach initiative in Indonesia.The final draft NAP is still in progress to be endorsed by the Minister of Health and other ministries. This task is delayed due to the pandemic situation that made ministries are still focused to COVID-19 response. However, the implementation on the planned activities has been carried out by ministries and stakeholders.

National Center for Disease Control (NCDC) is the national coordinating center for AMR surveillance in India and is coordinating National programme on AMR Containment. Under this programme, National AMR surveillance network has been established during 2014-15. Network began with 10 sites and has been gradually expanded to 29 sites in 24 states. India has two other AMR surveillance networks : one being coordinated by ICMR (Indian Council of Medical Research) and the other is GASP. Apart from submitting the data from the National AMR surveillance, NCDC coordinates with the other two AMR surveillance networks in India and submits their data to GLASS

100% participation in EARS-Net surveillance in Ireland and consistently >95% since 2007. Ireland's EARS-Net data is reported to ECDC and in turn shared with WHO GLASS Surveillance of newly confirmed CPE colonisation or infection has been evolving in Ireland since 2011, with transition from voluntary to mandatory to statutorily notifiable since December 2018.

Iran has developed its National Action Plan on AMR with promotion and development of AMR surveillance included in the NAP. Iran has been enrolled in GLASS since May 2016.The priority Bug -drug combinations are determined according to GLASS recommendations and national needs.Eight surveillance sites currently collect the necessary data and the number is going to be increased in a stepwise manner.
AMR

The National Antibiotic Resistance Surveillance System (AR-ISS)  has been running since 2001 under the coordination of Istituto Superiore di Sanità (ISS) and has enrolled hospital microbiology laboratories  over the country to provide AST data following the EARS-Net (previously EARSS) protocols. AST results regarding 8 bacterial pathogens obtained from blood or CSF are collected yearly and analysed at ISS, and then transmitted to ECDC. Every year the laboratories participate to an EQA program, distributed by ECDC. Ad-hoc microbiology studies on pathogens of special relevance for the country (e.g. Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae) are organized with the collection of isolates from the laboratories. In the framework of the Italian National Plan to contrast AMR (PNCAR) AR-ISS has been implemented to obtain a better representatively of the country with the active involvement of all the Italian Regions and Autonomous Provinces that are responsible for planning and managing the health system at the local level. In 2019 AR-ISS included all the Italian Regions and Autonomous Provinces with the participation of 130 hospital laboratories and the inclusions of Regional AMR networks, where present. The hospitals served by the 130 laboratories covered approximately 41% of the hospital patient-days.

Current country AMR surveillance in Japan comprises two systems:  AMR surveillance in National Epidemiological Surveillance of Infectious Diseases (NESID) and Japan Nosocomial Infections Surveillance (JANIS).   NESID AMR surveillance consists of pathogen reporting (laboratory-based surveillance) and patient reporting. The information is based on reporting from physicians. The system is pursuant to Articles 12 through 16 of the Act on the Prevention of Infectious Diseases, and Medical Care for Patients with Infectious Diseases in effect since April 1, 1999. Notifiable infectious diseases in NESID AMR surveillance are carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteraceae infection, vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection, vancomycin-resistant enterococcal infection, multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter infection all of which belong to category V infectious diseases and diseases to be reported by designated sentinel sites are methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection and multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection. JANIS collects comprehensive specimen-based data (i.e., both culture-positive and -negative data of all sample types) from diagnostic microbiology laboratories of participating hospitals to monitor the isolation rate of 11 major bacteria and specific AMR bacteria and creating antibiograms of approximately 20 bacterial species.  The comprehensive data collection scheme enabled JANIS to determine the total number of patients from whom the specimens were collected.  The data are regularly uploaded from hospitals through a web interface to a secure cloud system, according to a specific data format for each sample. Automatic data preparation functions have been developed and installed in automated microbiology systems such as MicroScan or Vitek or within the laboratory information systems used in the participating hospitals and commercial clinical laboratories. The uploaded data were stored in a database and processed in the JANIS server-side tabulation program. After automatic data check and de-duplication, Resistant-Intermediate-Susceptible (R-I-S) interpretation of the quantitative susceptibility test data was conducted using the 2012 version of CLSI breakpoints, enabling direct comparison of resistance rates among participating hospitals and monitoring the longitudinal trend of AMR. The JANIS server-side program then creates annual national reports. In addition, the JANIS server-side program also creates individual facility feedback reports, which are returned to each participating hospital and readily highlight the facility-specific isolation and resistance rates of specific AMR bacteria for each hospital compared to the national distribution of the previous year.

We have 5 human health laboratories submitting data to the national database and we are in the process of cleaning and preparing AMR reports for the next data call. We are preparing more human health labs and we expect to start receiving data from the 8 sites by December 2020.  We are also preparing 6 animal health labs which we expect to start receiving their data by February next year

The Cambodian Ministry of Health endorsed and launched the Laboratory-Based Antimicrobial Sentinel Surveillance Standard Operation Procedure (SOP) in November 2017. The implementation of the SOP started in January 2018 in eight sentinel sites: three sites in the capital Phnom Penh and five in four other provinces (see map below).  Those sentinel sites are classified into Tier 1 (HOPE Centre, Angkor Hospital for Children, Takeo Provincial Hospital and Battambang Provincial Hospital) and Tier 2 (National Pediatric Hospital, Calmette Hospital, Kampong Cham Provincial Hospital, and Siem Reap Provincial Hospital). AMR Surveillance Sentinel Sites in Cambodia (N=8) collects data and report monthly; 5 sites directly enter data into the laboratory information system (CamLIS) and extract to the AMR web-based reporting system. The remaining 3 sites complete an excel database, which is then sent the national AMR surveillance secretariat to be uploaded to AMR web-based reporting.  5 sentinel sites sent isolates to NRL for confirmatory testing including for identification and AST. NRL provides feedback on the discrepancy results to the AMR sentinel sites.  There is a monthly meeting for the AMR Technical Working Group to discuss progress and challenges with partners, the animal health sector, and environment colleagues. The national AMR surveillance team conducts quarterly supervision to each site using a standard checklist to strengthen microbiology, AMR reporting, infection prevention and control, and rational use of antibiotics.  The annual AMR surveillance review workshops were conducted to review the progress and challenges of implementing surveillance and the development of local action plans to strengthen surveillance.  One of the priorities for 2021 is to regularly analyze the surveillance data and produce a quarterly AMR surveillance bulletin and to enhance the use AMR data for improving infection control and rational use of antibiotics in the hospitals.
Depenging on the domestic situation, it is adding pathogens and examining resistant genes or virulence genes.

ncc_established_name: Department of Communicable Disease Control, Ministry of Health
ncc_established_address: Ban Thatkhao, Sisattanak District, Simeuang Road, Vientiane capital
nrl_designated_name: National Center for Laboratory and Epidemiology
nrl_designated_address: Thadeua Road, Km3, Thaphalanxay Village, Sisattanak District, Vientiane Capital
description: In 2020, Lao PDR has been expanding its national AMR surveillance system. In addition to the NCC, NRL and 3 surveillance sites (1 existing, 2 new) established in 2019, 4 further surveillance site were established in 2020. This is being guided by the Surveillance Strategy for an AMR Surveillance System in Lao PDR and related protocols, which were endorsed and disseminated in March 2020. NCLE and each surveillance site are receiving ongoing training and capacity building, as well as regular monitoring and evaluation. Monitoring of antimicrobial consumption (AMC) occurs at the national level, with country data compiled for 2018 and 2019. This is ready to be shared on the GLASS platform when the module becomes available. Hospital level AMC monitoring has started in 2020 in 3 sites which are also AMR surveillance sites.

The global emergence of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is posing a threat to human health.  AMR Surveillance is a systematic, ongoing data collection, analysis and reporting process that monitors temporal trends in the occurrence and distribution of susceptibility and resistance to antimicrobial agents, and provides information useful as a guide to medical practice, including therapeutics and disease control activities. Putting resources into the containment of AMR ? including surveillance ? is one of the highest-yield investments that should be made to mitigate its impact.  In Lebanon, the main activities that are achieved  related  to AMR surveillance: 1- Ensure sustainability of AMR data Reporting to GLASS: laboratories that provided microbiologically reliable and epidemiologically representative data to be uploaded to GLASS platform were: -  Two laboratories in 2017, -  Four laboratories in 2018, -  Eight laboratories in 2019. 2-Whonet training done for 32 hospitals both in human and animal sectors 3- AMR Proficiency Testing activities were achieved for: - 32 labs (2015-2016) - 80 labs (2019)

Because of the civil war that toke hold of the country during the last few years and the deteriorating of the health services, most of the selected surveillance sites were not able to function and start collecting data. With one exception of the Tripoli University Hospital, which despite its  location in a war zone  and the shutdown many times and the loss of the data was able to salvage the log books and re-enter most of the 2019 data into system.

Surveillance on antimicrobial resistance has been carried out since 2009 in Sri Lanka, at a limited number of hospital laboratories. The programme was further strengthened and upgraded in 2018 to include 25 hospital laboratories covering all parts of the country. Establishment of the National Surveillance System for Antimicrobial resistance in Sri Lanka was commenced in August 2017, by the Ministry of Health through the National Advisory Committee on Antimicrobial Resistance and supported by the WHO country office. Each sector will develop their own surveillance system and finally come together under one health approach.  The National Protocol for Antimicrobial resistance Surveillance for human health sector was developed in 2018 and data collection initiated by June 2018. The surveillance system functions under the supervision and authority of the National focal point for antimicrobial resistance, the Deputy Director General for Laboratory Services. The National Coordinating Center for the surveillance system is formed and the National Reference Laboratory for the system is also identified. Twenty five (25) state sector hospital laboratories that cover the whole island are identified as sentinel sites.  Data pertaining to antimicrobial resistance are collected from these hospital laboratories monthly, using the ?WHONET? software. Data is analyzed quarterly and a committee for data analysis and interpretation is established consisting of Health Administrators, Microbiologists and Epidemiologists and Medical officers having qualifications in Bio informatics. Sri Lanka became a member of the GLASS in 2018 and participated for the data call in 2019 for the first time.  Following the ?One Health? approach, the animal  sector is also to develop their own antimicrobial resistance surveillance system.   Priority specimens This survey covers following specimen types.  ?	Blood ?	Urine ?	Faeces/Stool ?	Urethral  ?	Cervical swabs   Priority pathogens This survey monitors the following pathogens only. ?	Escherichia coli ?	Klebsiella pneumoniae ?	Acinetobacter baumannii ?	Staphylococcus aureus ?	Streptococcus pneumoniae ?	Pseudomonas aeruginosa ?	Salmonella spp. ?	Shigella spp. ?	Neisseria gonorrhoeae   Data aggregation During the data collection for year 2019 out of the identified sentinel sites, the below list of hospitals have submitted data to the Surveillance system.  1.	Lady Ridge way hospital  / Colombo 2.	Medical Research Institute/ Colombo 3.	Sri Jayawardhanapura  General Hospital/ Jayawardenapura 4.	District General  Hospital / Matara 5.	District General hospital  / Polonnaruwa 6.	Provincial General hospital   / Badulla 7.	Colombo North Teaching Hospital / Ragama (NCTH) 8.	 District General  Hospital / Chilaw 9.	Apeksha hospital (National Cancer institute), Maharagama  10.	District General hospital, Ampara 11.	Teaching Hospital /Anuradhapura 12.	Teaching Hospital / Kandy 13.	Teaching Hospital / Peradeniya 14.	Teaching Hospital / Kurunegala 15.	Teaching hospital, Batticaloa  16.	Teaching hospital, Monaragala 17.	Provincial General hospital, Ratanapura  18.	Teaching hospital, Kegalle    Best Practices and way forward ?	Capacity building programmes on using WHONET for data collection, aggregation and basic analysis, were conducted for all sentinel site staff involved in human health sector and for selected staff of animal health sector in 2018 ?	Laptops were distributed to all sentinel sites of human health sector to conduct the data collection at each of these sites in 2018 ?	On site monitoring and evaluation of the surveillance sites was conducted in 2019 present where each of these 25 sites were visited by the staff of National coordinating Center and   capacity building and data collection activities were also carried. ?	More focus will be put into data analysis, interpretation dissemination of results in 2020.

Dans le cadre du plan, une plateforme de centralisation des données relatives à l?antibiorésistance provenant du secteur humain et vétérinaire sera mise en place sous la responsabilité du LNS (Laboratoire national de santé). Les principales activités liées à la mise en place de cette plateforme seront de centraliser l?ensemble des données de résistances en santé humaine et animale au Luxembourg, d?analyser et d?interpréter les données au niveau national et de réaliser un suivi épidémiologique de la situation nationale face à l?antibiorésistance. L?ensemble de ces activités a pour objectif d?améliorer les connaissances sur l?antibiorésistance au Luxembourg et d?identifier les actions à mettre en place afin de lutter contre l?émergence de résistances nouvelles. »

For the 8 public health laboratories, data GLASS submission is only for laboratories that have participated in EQA and have capacity building under the support of private partener . The one NRL have international certificate for EQA : Accreditation NF EN ISO 15189 par la comité Francaise d'accréditation COFRAC

-	STRUCTURE OF AMR SURVEILLANCE IN MALI: -	a coordination structure for AMR surveillance in Mali which is the INSP (National Institute of Public Health) which collaborates with the Directorate of Pharmacy and Drugs (DPM)  and other services. -	 a focal point to monitor the project in collaboration with WHO (Dr Guindo, laboratory manager at INSP) with access to GLASS SYSTEM -	1 national reference laboratory identified (INSP) -	05 identified and functional surveillance sites for a pilot phase (02 in Bamako and 03 in the regions). -	Terms of reference of the integrated AMR surveillance technical group (Group 2) for a ?One Health? approach available. -	Availability of WHONET software for the management and sharing of resistance data to the lab.

The microbiology laboratory at Mater Dei Hospital provides diagnostic services to all publically provided primary, secondary and tertiary care. It is estimated that this covers more than 95% of inpatient care. There is no national AMR surveillance in Malta but data from with bacteraemia in the country. The country has been a participant in EARS-NET (and previously EARSS) since 1999 and has been enrolled in GLASS since July 2017. Malta has published a comprehensive National AMR Strategy and Action Plan which is accessible on the website of the National Antibiotic Committee (www.nac.gov.mt).

National multi-sectoral steering committee (NMSC) combating Myanmar was endorsed on 22nd January 2018, consisting of 19 members in multi-sectoral and one health approach. Furthermore, WHO listed National Coordinating Centre (NCC) located at NHL, Yangon was established in June 2018. Under the supervision of NCC, there are five Technical Working Groups (TWGs) that are responsible for implementation of National Action Plan for containment of antimicrobial resistance (NAP AMR) through specialized coordinating units including Awareness, Surveillance, Infection Prevention and Control, Antimicrobial Usage and Research and innovation.   NCC established 7 as pilot areas for surveillance of AMR in the country. Those sentinel sites include National Health Laboratory, Yangon General Hospital, New Yangon General Hospital, North Okkalapa General and Teaching Hospital, Thingangyun General Hospital, 1000-bedded Naypyitaw Hospital and Mandalay General Hospital. Culture and sensitivity results of routine clinical specimens from seven sentinel hospitals were sent to their own hospital based laboratory where AMR data were entered into WHONET system. All staffs and professionals involved in AMR surveillance had already been trained how to use WHONET software and how to analyze data by WHO consultants. After data collection, those data were sent to NCC quarterly. NCC monitored and analyzed all pathogens, particularly WHO high priority pathogens such as Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter species, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterococcus species, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Salmonella species, Shigella species, Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Moreover, National Reference Laboratory (NRL) provides technical support to all hospital-based laboratories from seven sentinel sites. National External Quality Assessment Schemes (NEQAS) at NRL assess the culture and sensitivity testing capacities of sentinel sites. Furthermore, NRL/NHL participates in international EQAS programmes organized by National Institute of Health, Thailand (For bacteria culture and sensitivity testing) and One World Accuracy, Canada (For methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus and carbapenem resistant enterobacteriaceae). On the other hand, National AMR Surveillance Guideline has already finalized since April 2020 with the support of WHO, but it remained pending to launch due to COVID crisis. Myanmar had enrolled GLASS for AMR since 2018 and AMR data of Myanmar was uploaded on GLASS platform starting from 2019.

Mozambique is in the second year of AMR surveillance, focusing on BSI identified as part of routine patient care at a general hospital in the peri urban area of Maputo City. The surveillance is being carried out by the Instituto Nacional de Saúde of Mozambique (INS, the National Institute of Health).

AMR data is currently paperbased. We have no electronic surveillance and hence no analysis is currently done. No input done on GLASS platform. AMR surveillance is manual by reviewing AST results in lab registers. Susceptibility rates is calculated based on all isolates from both laboratories for Salmonella, Campylobacter, pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenzae and gonococcus. For more frequently isolated organisms such as E.coli, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Acinetobacter, periodic surveys of susceptibility rates are conducted about every 3 years by retrospective review of results over a one-month period.

AMR surveillance is coordinated by the AMR coordinating Center in the Ministry of Health, guiding document called AMR surveillance is developed and implementation is underway, currently the are 8 sites who are enrolled in this surveillance, the sites submit data quarterly to the National AMR laboratory,  Malawi has a fleming fund country grant and all the 8 sites are priority site in the implementation of this grant,, surveillance is being strengthened with resources from the grant

The National Surveillance of Antibiotic Resistance was established in 2000 and started with only 6 major hospitals and gradually increased to 42 hospitals and 1 Public Health laboratory in 2020. Antibiotic susceptibility data from the participating laboratories are sent to the Institute for Medical Research (IMR), Ministry of Health Malaysia every 3 monthly. The IMR is the national reference laboratory (NRL) for AMR surveillance for human. The IMR is also the laboratory that is providing the national EQA for identification and AST. Surveillance on Multi-drug resistant bacteria, such as ESBL E. coli and Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae are carried out by the Infection Control Unit of the Medical Development Division which collects data from major hospitals every quarterly.  The IMR also conducted yearly courses on the use of WHONET program.

Currently, 22 surveillance sites are under AMR surveillance including 21 from human health sector and one from the Animal health sector. The data reporting for AMR surveillance is through electronic as well as paper-based form from most sites. Few sites are unable to send data due to various reasons such as unavailability of human resources or computer or internet. Training regarding WHONET and data entry and analysis was provided to AMR surveillance site personnel with the help of Fleming Fund Country Grant and data was made available with facilitation from FFCG too.
The surveillance capacity continue to include same site as per last data call with no changes.

Pakistan started AMR surveillance system with enrollment in GLASS in 2017. In 2019 Pakistan AMR Surveillance System has been established. The primary goal of the Pakistan AMR surveillance system is to generate evidence on the burden of antimicrobial drug resistance among priority pathogens isolated from in-patient clinical samples in acute care hospitals throughout Pakistan for informed decision making or for enhancing the response to AMR. The system started with five sentinel sites; in 2018 four new sites are included and in 2019, 11 new sites are added to the system. The sites fulfill the minimum criteria to be included as sentinel site that include Agreement to participate and share requested data, Agreement to participate in lab assessments, Functional laboratory information management system (LIMS), which can export defined data as a flat file database, Participation in an accepted external quality assurance (EQA) program for bacteriology including culture, identification, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST), Agreement to participate in NEQAS and Standardized Lab SOPs for quality assurance.

Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Program (ARSP) The Philippines Department of Health?s national AMR surveillance ? the Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Program (DOH-ARSP) ? is a sentinel laboratory based surveillance established in 1988. It has 24 sentinel sites and 2 gonorrhea surveillance sites.  The sentinel sites participate in an external quality assessment scheme (EQAS) to ensure quality of laboratory results. Periodic monitoring visits to sentinel sites are likewise done. All sentinel sites implement standard methods for culture and susceptibility testing based on the WHO Manual for the Laboratory Identification and Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing of Bacterial Pathogens of Public Health Importance in the Developing World and updated Clinical Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) references for antibiotic susceptibility testing and quality control.   Using a standard format, routine culture and antimicrobial susceptibility test results are sent by the sentinel sites to the coordinating laboratory of the program? the Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance Reference Laboratory (ARSRL) at the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine. Sentinel sites likewise send isolates with unusual antimicrobial susceptibility patterns to ARSRL for confirmatory testing.  The culture and antimicrobial susceptibility test results are encoded using WHONET. The ARSRL?s Data Management Unit manages the cleaning, analysis, storage and security of the program?s surveillance data.  TESTING METHODS. At the reference laboratory, all referred isolates with unusual susceptibility patterns are re-identified using both automated (Vitek) and convention methods.  Both minimum inhibitor concentration (MIC) via automated method (Vitek) and disk diffusion are employed in antimicrobial susceptibility testing.   Further confirmatory tests are done such as: serotyping for S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, Salmonellae, and Vibrio cholerae; and identification of genes conferring antimicrobial resistance by multiplex PCR.   In the analysis of antimicrobial susceptibility testing, an isolate is considered resistant to an antimicrobial agent when tested and interpreted as resistant (R) in accordance with the clinical breakpoint criteria based on the most recent Clinical Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) references for antibiotic susceptibility testing. DATA ANALYSIS. Analysis is restricted to the first isolate received (per genus under surveillance) per patient in the calendar year. Data are expressed as a cumulative resistance percentage, i.e. the percentage of resistant isolates out of all isolates with antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) information on that specific organism?antimicrobial agent combination. Only species with testing data for 30 or more isolates are included in the analysis. An annual report with a summary of the surveillance data focusing on aerobic bacterial pathogens of public health importance causing common infectious diseases with significant morbidity and mortality locally are disseminated to the program?s stakeholders.

Data reported to the AMR surveillance are obtained from laboratories participating in EARS-Net. The national EARS-Net coordination centre is located in the  National Reference Centre for Susceptibility Testing (NRCST). All EARS-Net laboratories participate in the National External Quality Programme POLMICRO. The POLMICRO provides the laboratories with a sets of strains with different AMR resistance mechanism for identification and antimicrobial susceptibility testing. Clinical laboratories providing microbiological diagnostics for hospitals and outpatient facilities may send to NRCST the strains with important AMR mechanism for reference diagnostics. NRCST perform the reference diagnostics mostly for carbapenem resistant Enterobacterales, Pseudomonas spp. or Acinetobacter spp. and vancomycin-resistant enterococci.  Data of the number of the strains with confirmed resistance mechanisms are published on the NRCST website. Once a year each hospital obligatory make the analysis of the AMR alert pathogens such as ESBL-producers, carbapenem resistant strains, MRSA, VRE, penicillin non-susceptible pneumococci and send the report the District Sanitary Inspectorate. Aggregated data are collected by the Voivodeship and Chef Sanitary Inspectorate, but those data are not publicly available. Hospitals are also obliged to report the AMR outbreaks to sanitary inspection.  Aggregated data on the number of the AMR outbreaks are published in the Chief Sanitary Inspectorate annual report. Structure surveys focused on specific AMR problems (MRSA, ESBL producers, carbapenemase producers) are organized from time to time by different research institutions. The results of such surveys are publish in the scientific journals

Palestine is approved to be one member of GLASS , We are in the way to have national AMR lab who will receive bacterial isolates from different sentinel labs for final confirmation , AST and identify MDRO . We are in the way to establish WGS for the bacterial isolates to work in the genetic level of the resistance bacteria according WHO criteria but this needs lab materials and training.  According COVID 19 some, activities are stopped. We prepare national action plan for AMR but it needs approval and implementation and as you know there are some obstacles as COVID-19 and funding .  AMR Surveillance is limited now for 13 MoH  lab Hospitals and not  included other lab or vet labs yet .

National AMR Surveillance network comprises about 50 laboratories that provide microbiological service for more than 55 medical facilities. The central laboratory of Institute of Antimicrobial Chemotherapy annually collects from each participating medical centre (hospital) up to 150 consecutive non-duplicate (one of each species per patient/case of infection) clinical isolates together with accompanying case report forms (CRFs) containing anonymous patient clinical data and epidemiological data, including: source of infection (community- or hospital-acquired, as defined according to standard WHO and CDC criteria), geographical origin, ward type, site of infection, specimen type, date of collection, and patient age. In the central laboratory of IAC, the data recorded in CRFs are checked for consistency, the isolates are submitted to mandatory species re-identification, AST and long-term storage. The AST of isolates to extended panel of antimicrobial agents is performed by reference dilution methods according to ISO 20776 and EUCAST methodology. Based on resistance phenotypes, selected isolates are subjected to molecular detection of important genetic resistance determinants (e.g. Enterobacterales, Pseudomonas and Acinetobacter isolates with reduced susceptibility to carbapenems are tested by real-time PCR or sequencing for acquired carbapenemase genes according to EUCAST recommendations). Subsets of AST results for the isolates from blood and CSF cultures yielding organisms specified by CAESAR from the AMR surveillance study have been submitted for CAESAR since 2015 annually.  CAESAR data in 2019 comprise of the site local data collected according to CAESAR protocol.

ncc_established_name: Antimicrobial Resistance Coordination Office (AMRCO), National Centre for Infectious Diseases
nrl_designated_address: National Centre for Infectious Diseases, 16 Jalan Tan Tock Seng, Singapore 308442
description: Singapore has been conducting surveillance of AMR since 2011. AMR surveillance in human health is overseen by the National Antimicrobial Resistance Control Committee (NARCC), which is appointed by the Ministry of Health. NARCC collects, integrates and analyses data on AMR, antimicrobial utilisation and stewardship from all acute care hospitals twice yearly and provides the information annually to the hospitals and the Ministry of Health.  Hospital laboratories provide the AMR surveillance data, while the National Public Health Laboratory serves as the National Reference Laboratory for examining new and emerging resistance. NARCC is supported by two expert panels: the National Antimicrobial Resistance Expert Panel (NAREP), and the National Antimicrobial Stewardship Expert Panel (NASEP), which advise NARCC on issues related to surveillance of antimicrobial-resistant organisms, monitoring of antimicrobial use and antimicrobial stewardship. NARCC is further supported by the Antimicrobial Resistance Coordinating Office (AMRCO) which serves as Secretariat and national coordinating centre.  Gonococcal surveillance data is compiled by the Department of STI Control (DSC), which runs the National STI Control Programme for the Ministry of Health, and has been reported to GASP yearly. Singapore?s National Strategic Action Plan was launched in 2017 and has been enrolled in GLASS since September 2019.

Sweden has been conducting surveillance of AMR since mid-1990s. The Public Health Agency of Sweden is coordinating the national surveillance of notifiable resistance as well as data from voluntary participation of the laboratories. Sweden participates in EARSnet since 1998. The Public Health Agency of Sweden and the National Veterinary Institute analyse and compile national data on antibiotic sales and resistance in an annual report, SWEDRES/SVARM (published in English). National strategies on antimicrobial resistance were released in 2000, 2006 and 2016. In 2017 a new revised AMR national action plan was developed. Sweden has been enrolled in GLASS since 2016.

we because of covid-19 epidemic delayed the activities of AMR by minister order so we still in the same step of last year so we :  - defined 4  laboratories  to begin sharing data in GLASS program as a starter - begin training on protocol of manual  AST (zone diameter) -primer assessment of these labs -Work to provide these laboratories with data entry requirements. -training on WHONET  but unfortunately  some of them are left  employment -and supply the NRL with aoutomated Phoenex system.

At present, the National AMR surveillance system (NARST) consists of 102 sites ( 90 MoPH hospitals, 7 university hospitals, 1 military hospital, 1 metropolitan hospital and 3 private hospitals). Data are collected quarterly and are analysed at national and regional level. This information (e.g., antibiogram and resistance trend) is available on http://narst.dmsc.moph.go.th. To ensure quality of data, all sites receive National EQAs twice a year. This year 5 site visits are scheduled to surveillance sites where EQA results are unacceptable or no data submission. All sites are required to submit unusual or suspected emerging AMR organisms to the NRL (NIH, MoPH), and confirmation results are further sent to the Bureau of Epidemiology for investigation.

Establish a national coordination structure for surveillance of AMR in the MoH and the MoAF : The technical working group will identify a National Coordination Centre (NCC), define its mandates and terms of reference and designate a National Focal Point followed by notification by ministerial dispatch. The NCC will be located in the MoH/ National Health Laboratory (NHL) and Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory (VDL) in the MoAF. Establish National AMR Surveillance Unit, within the NHL in the MoH, and National VDL in the MoAF. Under the technical guidance of NCC and technical support from WHO, OIE and FAO, The MoH (National Laboratory and Hospital Laboratory) and MoAF (Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory) will develop guidelines for AMR Surveillance including guidelines for data sharing (indicators, triggers, analysis plan, response plan), incorporating the critical components as outlined in guidance documents (WHO sample templates, GLASS implementation guide, AGISAR technical recommendations, OIE, Codex, etc). The NCC will identify priority pathogens, sample sites and pathogen-antimicrobials combinations in humans and animals, based on the country?s AMR situation. NCC will develop a One Health AMR surveillance plan in humans, animal and food (sample selection, number of samples, sample processing, logistics). NCC will assess and inventory resources for monitoring, surveillance and testing sentinel environmental sites for antimicrobial resistant organisms and antimicrobial agents. NCC will train surveillance staff and clinical staff in AMR surveillance and lab techniques according to GLASS standards. NCC will develop an integrated human and animal IT platform for AMR surveillance reporting. WHONET platform will be implemented for AMR surveillance data entry, storage and transmission. NCC will implement a national AMR surveillance program that is representative of the country situation but with limited number of operational sites. Maliana and Baucau Municipality will be targeted in the pilot phase. Regular data of AMR along with resistance profiles of priority pathogens for human, animal and food will be made available to NCC from limited number of sites in the two target municipalities. The NCC will establish formal linkages between national AMR surveillance programme and WHO GLASS. Reporting to GLASS will commence after formal assessment of national AMR surveillance program pilots. TWG (Surveillance) will conduct a formal assessment of National AMR surveillance followed by recommendations of nationwide scale up.

The Country does not have a designated National Coordination Center (NCC) separate from A National Reference Lab (NRL).  There is a Medical Microbiologist who is the data Manager and he servers at one Centre which has dual roles of NRL and NCC.  We have Regional Reference Laboratory Service (RRL) and Coordination being developed with the Caribbean Community (CARICOM) with the assistance of the Pan American Health Organization and Argentina through a Country Cooperation for Health Development (CCHD) project. A Regional Reference Laboratory (RRL) such as The Caribbean Public Health Agency's (CARPHA) Medical Microbiology Laboratory is suggested. The is a Regional Coordination Centre Located in the Special AMR program at the Pan American Health Organization.  Trinidad and Tobago is a small country, like many in the Caribbean and having a RRL would be ideal especially with the existing AMR Special Program at the Pan American Health Organization.  We will try to submit data. If not this year, next year for sure.  The National Focal Point is Dr Rajeev P Nagassar

National level coordination of AMR surveillance is In the process of being set up. However, Since 1999, a voluntary microbiologist group provided data on antibiotic resistance. Laboratory capacity available to surveillance sites and availability of routine AST data; Currently, 8 sites are equipped with SIRScan software, have reliable data. All these sites use the same methodology (CA-SFM, EUCAST) and the same criteria for Interpretation. Data management and quality control; The 8 labs use the same criteria for elimination of epidemiological duplicates Weekly Internal Quality control & annually National External Quality Control  (Ministry of health).   Since last year,  we benefited from technical assistance from the EMRO office for the preparation of the GLASS aggregated data. This year, with the COVID-19 pandemia, somes participating labs have problem to prepare their data. Thus, we wish to have an extension of the deadlines

Tanzania has been building a robust system of data collection at the surveillance sites. We are now at the initial stage on the implementation of data collection, but we have started to collect data for trial from June 2020 and we could submit next year during data call.

There is a Technical team involved in training, standardization and Quality Assurance activities that take place at the coordinating AMR Laboratory, the National center, the site coordination and site laboratories. This team operates in liaison with the National coordinator and multi-sectoral National coordinating center as well as the site coordinator and multidisciplinary site coordinating committee. All the activities including capacity building are supported by external funding organizations in form of financing, monitoring and Technical advice. The regional hospitals, STI clinics, site laboratories and other health centers that can carry out specimen cultures, send isolates or report to the site coordination center /committee which in turn feeds the information to the National coordination center. Likewise, the samples can be sent from the Health centers and STI clinic to be analyzed at the National laboratory. A National Microbiology laboratory is in place .The Team at the National Microbiology laboratory. regularly carries out support supervision at the lower facilities to stimulate increase in volume and quality of isolates and data. Apart from central coordination, the National focal person here does respond to WHO-GLASS data preparation, review and upload.

AMR surveillance activities are coordinated by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in conjunction with other federal, state and local public health agencies. Surveillance is directed by several national networks, including the National Healthcare Safety Network (NHSN), the Emerging Infections Program (EIP), the National AMR Monitoring System (NARMS), the National TB Surveillance System (NTSS), the Antibiotic Resistance Laboratory Network (ARLN) and the Gonococcal Isolate Surveillance Project (GISP).

For GLASS in South Africa under the National Institute for Communicable Diseases (NICD) umbrella, three surveillance programmes are utilized for reporting the appropriate data. These surveillance programmes include GERMS-SA laboratory-based surveillance, NICD sentinel periodic surveillance for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and the National AMR routine electronic surveillance. GERMS-SA is a robust national laboratory-based population surveillance program for HIV-associated bacterial and fungal opportunistic infections, vaccine-preventable diseases, healthcare-associated bloodstream infections, and HIV-associated opportunistic infections. The Streptococcus pneumoniae data reported to GLASS is extracted from this program. The CLSI guideline is used. NICD conducts sentinel periodic surveillance of STIs. Syndromes under surveillance are male urethritis syndrome, vaginal discharge syndrome, and genital ulcer syndrome. The STI data reported to GLASS use EUCAST guidelines. The National AMR routine electronic surveillance is in accordance with the South African National Antimicrobial Resistance Strategy of the National Department of Health and supported by the South African Society for Clinical Microbiology. Data derived from blood culture, and stool specimens for all public health facilities (including all levels of care, military, and prisons) are collated by the NICD?s Surveillance Data Warehouse and presented on a dashboard. The CLSI guideline is used.

AMR SURVEILLANCE STRUCTURE The National multi-sectorial steering committee (NMSC) oversees and monitors activities of the Antimicrobial Resistance Coordinating Committee (AMRCC) whose chairperson is a member of NMSC. The AMRCC is composed of sector-specific focal point persons and heads of technical working groups (TWGs). AMRCC coordinates AMR surveillance activity implementation through the National Surveillance Coordination Centre.  Responsibilities of the AMRCC ?	Preparing and disseminating national surveillance protocols,  ?	Coordinating data collection, analysis and reporting at national level,  ?	Sharing national aggregated data with WHO on the Global Antimicrobial Resistance Surveillance System (GLASS). ?	Updating the Surveillance Sub-committee of the AMRCC on the status of AMR surveillance. ?	Monitoring and evaluating the national AMR surveillance system, ?	Designating a national AMR surveillance focal person to coordinate surveillance activities, data management and dissemination of surveillance reports, ?	Coordinating linkages between human and animal AMR surveillance programs ?	Training of human resource in various areas identified during needs assessment. This surveillance framework is designed to provide public health authorities guidance on facilitating the implementation of AMR surveillance in Zambia.  National Surveillance Coordination Centre AMR surveillance in Zambia is conducted using sentinel surveillance approach which is integrated into the National Integrated Disease Surveillance and Response (IDSR).  IDSR is undertaken at all levels of health care delivery from national, provincial and district to health centre level and provides an entry point for AMR surveillance.  The IDSR is spearheaded through the Surveillance and Disease Intelligence cluster of the Zambia National Public Health Institute (ZNPHI) which anchors the National Surveillance Coordination Centre.  AMR Surveillance Activities ?	Development of the National Integrated AMR Surveillance Strategy ?	Development of the national AMR Surveillance Framework ?	Prioritization of AMR surveillance activities in the National Action plan ?	Documentation of National AMR Baseline data from country situation analysis ?	Development of the National Antimicrobial Stewardship policy and Implementation framework with support from ReACT Africa network ?	Development of AMR surveillance Standard Operating procedures and Guidelines ?	AMR awareness raising activities ?	Refurbishment of laboratories at sentinel sites, procurement of equipment and laboratory supplies in both human and animal health through the support of the UK Fleming Fund country grant.  ?	Building capacity in identification of priority pathogens and Antimicrobial susceptibility testing in laboratories in selected AMR surveillance sentinel sites using the on-site mentorship approach in both human and animal health. ?	Development and operationalisation of the National One Health AMR database with the support from Foundation for Innovative Diagnostics (FIND) ?	Trainings in: o	Use of WHONET software for AST data management o	 End user training on the use of the National One Health AMR database o	Laboratory Biosafety and Biosecurity  ?	Participation in regional and International meetings on AMR ?	Submission of National AMR data to the Global Antimicrobial Surveillance System (GLASS)
